publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: ISynge of a Sermon, a Sermon of Worth,
Which newly was Printed, and newly come forth;A Sermon of late,Which rais'd a Debate,
And many Opinions, of Church and of State:
It was made by a Priest of six Foot and more,
But the like of it, scarce has been heard of before.
Most are at a loss to find out his true meaning;
Whilst others of some dark Design are complaining.Some think He's for Martin,Some for Jack his Heart in,
But most do agree He's for Peter, for certain:
O S────nge who won't think thou wert Bred at St. Germains,
Who reads what Opinions you've Broach'd in your Sermons.
Some say it is new, some say what is stranger;
That all you have said is taken from Bangor:Then looks it not odlyT'Extract from Ben Hoadly
A Scheme that seems Popish to all that are Godly.
O S────nge thou had'st better been hang'd in a Rope,
Than thus to turn Stickler for Rome and the Pope.
Now, who will not say you are for the Pretender,
When yo' oppose the true Faith, and the Faith's true Defender?For you open a DoorFor Babylon's Whore,
And for all Sects that are in the World, and much-more:
O S────nge thou had'st better have dy'd in thy Youth,
Than thus to be plagu'd for opposing the Truth.
This Sermon was lately attack'd in a Letter,
Which some People think might have been somewhat better;Be that as it will,He got a damn'd Pill,
Which in vain he since thought to expell by his Quill:
O S────nge thou had'st better by far held thy Peace,
Than thus to be slav'd by the Vicar of Naas.
Beware of this Vicar and dread his Attack,
For surely he'll lay you, at length, on your Back;For he shews you've perplex'dAnd murther'd your Text,
And quoted ────Of which you'll hear more in his next:
O S────nge thou had'st better a Blanket been tost in,
Than thus to be pelted for quoting St. Austin.
This Truth from Experience is always allow'd,
That Men of Low Parts may pass in the Crowd,Without vain pretenceTo superior sense,
Or more than kind Nature does wisely dispense;
But when they pretend to soar up 'bove their Pitch,
It is twenty to one, but they fall in a Ditch.
How-e'er he's abus'd here, he's sure that in Britain
He'll meet with Applause both from Whiston and Ditton.So S────nge be not Sh────t onBy Whiston or Ditton,
He cares not what Irish Folk say of what's written;Synge, Ditton and Whiston: Synge, Whiston and Ditton:
Synge, Shitt on and Pist on, Synge, Pist on and Shitt on.
